question:
(a) ldentify specimens A, B, and C.

      

(b) State the main nutrient(s) which can be released to the soil for crop's use by each of specimens A, B, and C.

(c) Name two other chemical substances which can be used as substitutes for specimen B

(d) State the major adverse effect of repeated applications of specimen B on a soil

(e) Mention the role of specimen C in;
(i) crop production,
(ii) fish production.

(f) Name other substances that can be used and Substituted for specimen C
answer:
a) ldentiflcation of specimens;

  • A - NPK fertilizer,
  • B - Ammonium Sulphate,
  • C - Lime

(b) The man nutrient(s) released by each specimen are:

  • Specimen A - Nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium,
  • Specimen B - Nitrogen
  • Specimen C -  Calcium,

(c) Ammonium Nitrate and urea can be used as substitutes for specimen B.

(d) it can increase the acidity of the soil

(e)(i) Role of specimen C in crop production ars,

  • it helps to reduce soil acidity
  • It increases the activities of soil living organisms,
  • It improves the soil structure.
  • It increases water percolation in soils.

(il) Role of Specimen C in fish production are.

  • It serves as additional source of calcium for bone development in fish.
  • It reduces turbidity in the fish ponds through flocculation,

(f) (i) Quick lime (ii) Slaked lime (iii) Basic Slag (iv) Dolomite (v) Calcium carbonate,

question:
(a) ldentify specimens D, E, F, G, H, and I.

               

(b) State one function of each of specimens D, E, F G, H, and I

(c) Mention one method of maintaining each of specimens D, E, F, G, H, and I.
answer:
(a) ldentification of specimens:

  • D - Measuring tape,
  • E - Budding knife,
  • F - Gunter's chain,
  • H - Spanner,
  • I - Screw driver

(b) Functions of each of the specimens are:

  • D is used in laking measurements of length, breadth and height.
  • E is used mainly in budding (by vegetative propagation) in citrus, cocoa, rubber etc.
  • F is used (i) for gripping firmly and twisting wires, (ii) for holding bolts and nuts,
  • G is used in taking short or detailed measurement of length and breadth.
  • H is used in loosening or tightening nuts/ bolts on farm machines
  • I is used for turning or screwing nails or screws into or out of wooden or metal surfaces and to detect the presence of electric current.

(c) Methods of maintaining each of the specimens are:

  • D - Clean after use,
  • E - Sharpen cutting edge regularly,
  • F - Oil or grease after use,
  • G - Store in a cool and dry place,
  • H - Oil or grease metal parts before storage
  • I -  use according to specification or for the intended purpose

question:
(a) ldentify specimens J, K, L, and M.

         

(b) Enumerate four types of damages done to crops by each of specimens K and L.

(c) State five methods of controlling specimen J.
answer:
(a) ldentification of specimens:

  • J - Leaf eating beetle,
  • K - Aphid,
  • L - Callosobruchus spp (bean beetle),
  • M - Termites or Mole Cricket

(b) Damage done to crops by specimens K and L are;

Specimen K (Aphid);

  • causes stunted growth
  • It causes galls on loaves,
  • It is a vector of diseases,

Specimen L (Callosobruchus spp);

  • They bore holes into grains and eat them up.
  • They reduce the quality of stored products,
  • They reduce grains to powder.

(c)(i) Spray with insecticides.
(ii) Hand pick them.
(iii) Use resistant varieties.
(iv) Early planting.
(v) Crop rotation.

question:
(a) ldentify specimen N, O, P and Q.

         

(b) Name the classes of farm animals from which each of specimens N and O can be obtained

(c) State the two functions of specimens N, O, and P that is common to farm animals

(d) Mention; (i) One industrial use of specimen O
(ii) One parasite of specimen O

(e) Name the condition in which an animal does not possess specimen Q

(f) State two importance of specimen Q to each of farm animal and man respectively
answer:
(a) Identify specimens;

  • N = Fresh skin of poultry fowl,
  • O = Fresh skin/hide of ruminant,
  • P = Kidney (whole) of goat,
  • Q = Horn

(b) Specimen N is derived from poultry birds such as domestic fowl, turkey, goose, duck etc while specimen O is derived from ruminant animals like cattle, sheep and goat.

(c) Two functions of specimens N, O, and P that are Common to farm animals are:

N -

  • It protects the internal organs.
  • It prevents the entrance of disease organisms

O -

  • It aids excretion,
  • It aids the production of milk in females.

P-

  • It aids excretion
  • It helps in the osmoregulation of the body.

(d)(i) It can be used to make shoes, belts, caps, baskets, drums, etc.

(ii) Tick, Liver fluke, tapeworm, or Ascaris,

(e) The condition in which an animal does not possess specimen Q is when the animal is a hon-ruminant.

(f) The importance of specimen Q to farm animals are;

  • It is used to fight or defend themsslves. 
  • It gives them shape
  • It aids swimming, e.g. kuri catle.

Importance of specimen Q to man are;

  • It serves as raw material in knife handles, belt heads etc.
  • it is used for decorative purposes.
  • It is used to make livestock feeds.
